intro: Ranunculus pentapetalus, commonly known as the five-petaled buttercup, is a herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its striking yellow flowers with five distinct petals. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring trifoliate leaves with serrated edges. Its flowers bloom in early spring, often in shades of yellow to orange, and are surrounded by a ring of sepals. Ranunculus pentapetalus is adapted to cool, moist environments and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky habitats.
